title: Week 1 Tutorial
text:
How to use this quiz



This quiz is designed as a formative self-assessment tool, not as a test.
Its purpose is to help you: - check your understanding of the key concepts from Topic 1, - identify which types of thinking you find more difficult, and - guide your revision before the tutorial and future assessments.


Each question belongs to one of four categories:

Subject Knowledge (SK): definitions, concepts, and facts.

Analysis (AN): understanding relationships and economic mechanisms.

Problem Solving (PS): applying concepts to new situations.

Mathematical Thinking (MT): working with ratios, prices, and scaling.

Your score will be broken down by category so you can see where you are strong and where you need more practice.




You may use your notes and the lecture materials.
Take your time — the goal is understanding, not speed.
Use the Hints if you get stuck.
You may refresh and retry the quiz as many times as you like.





A low score is not a problem — it tells you what to focus on.
If you score low in:

SK: revise definitions and core concepts.
AN: revisit the logic of the models and examples.
PS: practise applying concepts to new cases.
MT: practise the price and ratio calculations.





The leaderboard is optional and anonymous. It exists only to make practice more engaging.
It has no effect on your grade and is not used for evaluation.
The only purpose of this quiz is to support your learning.

title: Week 1 Tutorial
text:
Subject Knowledge

SK1) Which of the following is not one of the three economic roles of money?


 Medium of exchange Unit of account Store of value Means of production




Hint

The three roles concern valuation, exchange, and storage — not production activities.



SK2) Which role of money refers to its function as a generally accepted means of payment?


 Unit of account Medium of exchange Store of value Liquidity provider




Hint

The role that enables buying and selling is the Medium of Exchange.



SK3) Which role of money allows prices to be expressed and compared across goods?


 Store of value Medium of exchange Unit of account Asset




Hint

Prices can be compared only if money acts as a common measurement unit.



SK4) Which of the following best defines liquidity?


 The legal tender status of an asset The ease with which an asset can be exchanged for goods or other assets The interest paid by an asset The stability of an asset's price over time




Hint

Liquidity refers to how easily an asset can be exchanged, not to its return or price stability.



SK5) Which monetary aggregate is conventionally defined as “money” in modern economies?


 M0 M1 M2 M3




Hint

The conventional definition includes assets that can be used directly for payment.



SK6) Which of the following is not one of the four characteristics that underlie liquidity?


 Marketability Predictability of exchange value Divisibility Scarcity




Hint

Scarcity affects value, not the ease with which an asset can be exchanged.



SK7) Which of the following best explains why money is considered “intrinsically worthless” in modern economies?


 It has no legal status It is not backed by gold It has no direct consumption or production use It is issued by private banks




Hint

“Intrinsically worthless” means money has no direct consumption or production use.



SK8) Which of the following objects is an example of a Unit of Account that is not a Medium of Exchange?


 Euro banknotes Bitcoin IMF Special Drawing Rights (SDR) Gold




Hint

Some units exist only for accounting and pricing, not for everyday transactions.



SK9) Why does money’s role as a Store of Value logically follow from its role as a Medium of Exchange?


 Because money is durable Because money is scarce Because there is typically a time gap between selling and buying Because money earns interest




Hint

Because selling and buying are separated in time, money must store value between them.



SK10) Which statement best reflects the Classical view of money?


 Money directly affects real output Money is a veil over real economic activity Money determines the level of employment Money is essential for price formation




Hint

The Classical view treats money as neutral with respect to real economic outcomes.

title: Week 1 Tutorial
text:
Analysis

AN1) Why does barter require a “double coincidence of wants”?


 Because goods are indivisible Because both traders must want what the other offers Because prices cannot be defined Because barter requires legal contracts




Hint

Trade requires that each party wants what the other offers at the same time.



AN2) Why does the use of money reduce search costs relative to barter?


 Because prices become regulated Because money replaces goods Because traders only need to find someone who accepts money Because money increases production




Hint

With money, traders only need to find someone who accepts money, not a specific good.



AN3) Why does the existence of a Unit of Account reduce the informational burden in an economy?


 It eliminates uncertainty It reduces the number of relative prices that must be known It stabilises inflation It ensures fairness in trade




Hint

A Unit of Account reduces the number of prices that must be known and compared.



AN4) Why does money’s liquidity allow people to accept a lower financial return on it?


 Because money is scarce Because money is safe Because liquidity provides convenience and flexibility Because money is legally protected




Hint

People accept lower returns because liquidity itself is valuable.



AN5) Why does the Classical view regard money as a “veil”?


 Because money hides inequality Because money only affects nominal variables, not real outcomes Because money is unstable Because money is controlled by governments




Hint

The Classical view separates nominal prices from real economic outcomes.



AN6) Why does Keynes argue that money has macroeconomic importance beyond facilitating exchange?


 Because money determines wages Because changes in liquidity preference spill over into goods and asset markets Because money controls government budgets Because money is scarce




Hint

Changes in money demand spill over into spending and investment decisions.



AN7) Why is money’s role as Medium of Exchange insufficient on its own to guarantee efficient outcomes?


 Because prices may be regulated Because production may be limited Because coordination failures and liquidity hoarding can still occur Because money may depreciate




Hint

Even with money, hoarding and coordination failures can prevent efficient outcomes.



AN8) Why is liquidity described as both a property of assets and a property of the monetary system?


 Because central banks set liquidity Because liquidity depends on both asset characteristics and social acceptance Because liquidity is fixed over time Because liquidity is measurable in money units




Hint

Liquidity depends on asset features and on whether others accept it in exchange.



AN9) Why can an increase in the public’s desire for liquidity reduce aggregate demand?


 Because prices fall Because people substitute money for consumption and investment Because banks reduce lending Because wages fall




Hint

When people hold more money, they spend less, reducing aggregate demand.



AN10) Which of the following best captures the fundamental difference between Keynesian and Classical views of money?


 Keynes focuses on inflation; Classics focus on growth Keynes sees money as neutral; Classics do not Keynes emphasises coordination frictions; Classics assume they are negligible Keynes focuses on fiscal policy; Classics on monetary policy




Hint

The key difference is whether markets are assumed to coordinate automatically.

title: Week 1 Tutorial
text:
Problem Solving

PS1) Two traders meet: one has Apples and wants Bananas; the other has Bananas and wants Apples. What exchange friction is absent in this case?


 Search costs Misaligned preferences Double coincidence of wants Price uncertainty




Hint

When each trader wants what the other has, no matching friction arises.



PS2) Why does introducing money allow a trader to accept a good they do not want to consume?


 Because money increases utility directly Because money can be exchanged later for preferred goods Because money is scarce Because money stabilises prices




Hint

People accept money because it can later be exchanged for desired goods.



PS3) Three traders each prefer a good they do not own. Why does no bilateral trade take place under barter?


 Prices are unknown Preferences are cyclical and misaligned Goods are indivisible Endowments are unequal




Hint

If preferences form a cycle, no pairwise trade satisfies both parties.



PS4) Why might a trader refuse to act as a “middleman” by accepting their least-preferred good?


 Because it reduces total surplus Because they risk being unable to trade it away later Because it violates rationality Because it is illegal




Hint

Accepting an unwanted good is risky if it cannot be traded away later.



PS5) Which institutional arrangement could replicate the role of money in a small economy?


 A central warehouse Multilateral simultaneous exchange Government price fixing Interest-bearing accounts




Hint

Multilateral exchange can replicate money but only if everyone coordinates simultaneously.



PS6) Why does multilateral exchange become impractical as the number of traders increases?


 Because preferences become unstable Because coordinating many participants simultaneously becomes difficult Because prices cannot be calculated Because goods become scarce




Hint

The more participants, the harder it becomes to coordinate simultaneous exchange.



PS7) Suppose people suddenly fear future shortages and increase their money holdings. What immediate effect is most likely?


 Increased consumption Reduced spending on goods and assets Higher production Increased inflation




Hint

Holding more money means postponing consumption and investment.



PS8) Which scenario best illustrates a coordination failure rather than a technological failure?


 A factory cannot produce enough output Traders fail to exchange even though mutually beneficial trades exist A machine breaks down A resource becomes depleted




Hint

The problem is not production but failure to realise mutually beneficial trades.



PS9) Why can increased liquidity preference cause a recession even when productive capacity is unchanged?


 Because wages fall Because firms become less efficient Because spending declines, reducing aggregate demand Because inflation rises




Hint

Lower spending reduces output even if productive capacity is unchanged.



PS10) Which policy is most directly aimed at counteracting a surge in liquidity hoarding?


 Raising interest rates Cutting taxes Expanding the money supply or lowering interest rates Reducing government spending




Hint

Lower interest rates or higher money supply make holding money less attractive.

title: Week 1 Tutorial
text:
Mathematical Thinking

MT1) In an economy with 2 goods, how many bilateral exchange ratios are needed without a unit of account?


 1 2 3 4




Hint

With two goods, there is only one pairwise price ratio.



MT2) In an economy with 3 goods, how many bilateral exchange ratios are required without money?


 2 3 4 6




Hint

The number of ratios equals the number of distinct good pairs.



MT3) In an economy with 5 goods, how many bilateral exchange ratios are needed?


 5 10 15 20




Hint

Use the combinatorial formula for choosing pairs.



MT4) If the price of Apples is \(P_A = 0.5\) and the price of Bananas is \(P_B = 0.25\), what is the exchange ratio of Bananas per Apple?


 0.5 1 2 4




Hint

Exchange ratios are obtained by dividing one price by another.



MT5) If \(P_A = 2\) and \(P_B = 4\), what is the exchange ratio of Apples per Banana?


 0.25 0.5 2 4




Hint

“Apples per Banana” is the inverse of “Bananas per Apple.”



MT6) An economy has 10 goods. Approximately how many exchange ratios are required without a unit of account?


 10 25 45 100




Hint

The number of ratios grows with n², not linearly.



MT7) If the number of goods doubles from 50 to 100, by approximately what factor does the number of exchange ratios increase?


 It doubles It triples It quadruples It increases tenfold




Hint

Because ratios grow with n², doubling goods quadruples ratios.



MT8) Suppose there are 700 goods. Approximately how many exchange ratios exist without money?


 70,000 140,000 245,000 490,000




Hint

For large n, n(n−1)/2 is approximately n²/2.



MT9) If \(P_A/P_B = 2\) and \(P_B/P_C = 3\), what is \(P_A/P_C\)?


 1.5 2 5 6




Hint

To combine relative prices, multiply the ratios.



MT10) If an economy introduces a unit of account, how does the informational burden of price knowledge scale with the number of goods \(n\)?


 Proportionally to n Proportionally to n log n Proportionally to n² It does not change




Hint

With a Unit of Account, only one price per good is required.
